#Text=Choose a Residential Contractor

#Text=When tasked with choosing a residential contractor , there are steps you can take to verify that the contractor is properly licensed and has the experience required to efficiently perform the task you hire them for .

#Text=Using the proper resources , you can research the professional background of a residential contractor and compare their fees and services to others in their profession . By following the steps outlined in this article , you can choose an ideal residential contractor that best suits your needs .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Seek referrals for residential contractors .
#Text=You can seek referrals from friends and family members , consumer protection agencies , or organizations that train or regulate contractors .

#Text=Visit the Better Business Bureau ( BBB ) website featured in the Sources section of this article , or call the BBB for feedback on a particular contractor at 1-703-276-0100 in the United States or at 514-905-3893 in Canada . ( Though this point in case of USA Builders only )
#Text=Consult with an organization that focuses on improving or that regulates the business of contracting , such as the National Association of Home Builders .
#Text=Organizations such as these may provide you with the contact information for reputable contractors who belong to the organization .
#Text=Verify that the residential contractor who was referred to you worked on a task similar to the task you are hiring them for .
#Text=For example , if you need to choose a residential contractor to work on your roof , you may not want to hire a residential contractor who specializes in installing air conditioning systems .
#Text=Verify if the residential contractor has a license as required by law .
#Text=Some states or regions may require residential contractors to obtain a license prior to practicing contracting business .
#Text=Consult with your state or region 's licensing regulator to determine if a contracting license is required by law to practice business .
#Text=Visit the " Contractor 's License " website provided to you in the Sources section of this article , then click directly on your state .
#Text=You will then be taken to a webpage that indicates if a license is required by the state , as well as contact information for the contracting regulator .
#Text=Ask the residential contractor to show you their license or certification prior to hiring them .
#Text=Verify that the residential contractor has insurance .

#Text=Hiring a residential contractor with insurance or worker 's compensation may protect you from lawsuits or from paying expenses in the event the contractor is injured while working on your property .
#Text=Ask the contractor to provide you with proof of insurance .
#Text=In most cases , residential contractors are required to have an insurance policy before they can legally perform contracting work .
#Text=Speak with references or past clients of the residential contractor .
#Text=This will allow you to determine if other consumers have had positive experiences with the contractor .
#Text=Obtain a list of references or past clients from the residential contractor .
#Text=The references can be clients with either positive , or negative experiences .
#Text=Contact each reference and ask them for details about their experience with the contractor .
#Text=If any references had issues with the contractor , obtain details about the problems and their outcomes .
#Text=This will allow you to determine if the contractor is experienced with handling and resolving problems that may arise while on the job .
#Text=Compare the fees and services of multiple contractors .
#Text=These factors may allow you to determine the value offered by each residential contractor .
#Text=Ask each residential contractor about the types of materials they will use , the amount of time it will take them to complete the project , and a complete list and description of each fee .
#Text=Some contractors may charge you lower prices if they are using materials that are lower in quality .
#Text=Review the contract provided to you by the residential contractor .
#Text=A reputable contractor will provide you with a detailed contract that outlines the terms , policies , guidelines , and timeline of the project .
#Text=Ask a friend , family member , or acquaintance familiar with contracts for help with understanding and reviewing the contract terms .
#Text=This may prevent you from signing a contract with terms that are unethical , unprofessional , or less than favorable .
#Text=Tips
#Text=If your state or region requires contractors to have a license , check directly with your state 's licensing board to see if the contractor has ever had formal complaints filed against them .
#Text=You may be able to review the nature of the complaint and whether a contractor 's license has ever been revoked or suspended .
